docs.lead_paragraph: Babies born to women with high levels of lead in their bones face the same sort of developmental problems as babies exposed to lead from sources like old paint, researchers reported yesterday. In an article in the journal Pediatrics, they said this type of lead exposure ''may constitute a significant public health problem, in view of the long residence time of lead in bone.''

headline.main: Dangers From Lead, in the Womb

docs.abstract: Study led by Dr Howard Hu of Havard, in report in journal Pediatrics, finds that babies born to women with high levels of lead in their bones face same kind of developmental problems as those exposed to lead from sources like old paint; suggests doctors may need to find ways to protect children before birth and public officials need to do more to protect women from lead exposure; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Babies born to women with high levels of lead in their bones face the same sort of developmental problems as babies exposed to lead from sources like old paint, researchers reported yesterday.    In an article in the journal Pediatrics, they said...

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a lot of time to think about life and baseball and how they intertwine when you are driving seven hours through the darkness from Columbus, Ohio, to New Jersey, which is what Chris Widger did early yesterday. For Widger, a minor leaguer who was becoming a major leaguer again with the Yankees, there is always a lot to ponder now. Everything changed drastically for him 13 months ago. Widger has five nieces, a set of quadruplets who are 3 1/2 years old and a 15-year-old, and they no longer have a mother. Widger's sister, Toni, died May 28, 2001, after a mixture of medications she was given to treat a staph infection stemming from the pregnancy caused her to go into toxic shock. She was 36. Playful and proud one day, she was dead the next.

headline.main: Widger's Story Isn't Just About Baseball

docs.abstract: Jack Curry On Baseball column discusses New York Yankees catcher Chris Widger, who wasjust called up from Class AAA Columbus team to play in majors and is happy to be closer to New Jersey home, where his brother-in-law Mike Murphy takes care of five children alone because Widger's sister Toni died suddenly of toxic shock; photo (M)
